results.name: Rectangular array T(k,n) of polygonal numbers, by antidiagonals.
comment: The antidiagonal sums 1, 4, 11, 25, 50, ... are the numbers A006522(n) for n>=3.
This is the accumulation array (Cf. A144112) of A144257 (which is the weight array of A086270). [_Clark Kimberling_, Sep 16 2008]

By rows, the sequence beginning (1, N,...) is the binomial transform of (1, (N-1), (N-2), 0, 0, 0,...); and is the second partial sum of (1, (N-2), (N-2), (N-2),...). Example: The sequence (1, 4, 9, 16, 25,...) is the binomial transform of (1, 3, 2, 0, 0, 0,...) and the second partial sum of (1, 2, 2, 2,...). - _Gary W. Adamson_, Aug 23 2015
link: Clark Kimberling and John E. Brown, Partial Complements and Transposable Dispersions, J. Integer Seqs., Vol. 7, 2004.
formula: 2*T(n, k) = T(n+r, k) + T(n-r, k), where r = 0, 1, 2, 3, ..., n-1 (see table in Example field). [_Bruno Berselli_, Dec 19 2014]
example: The array formed by the complements: A183225.
mathematica: t[n_, k_] := n*Binomial[k, 2] + k; Table[ t[k, n - k + 1], {n, 12}, {k, n}] // Flatten
program: (MAGMA) T:=func<h,i | h*Binomial(i,2)+i>; [T(k,n-k+1): k in [1..n], n in [1..12]]; // _Bruno Berselli_, Dec 19 2014
